bibl.title: Letter from Cornelia Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 4, 1952

div1.p: Cornelia Kean praises Hench's yellow fever history work, especially in specifying the important roles of both Reed and Finlay. She states her hopes that a memorial in Cuba will enshrine them both.

div1.head: Letter from Cornelia Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 4, 1952

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
4 August 1952

div1.p:
General Kean was so happy and pleased
with your unselfish devotion to the History
of Yellow Fever. He often said that you
knew more about it than any other
living man: that Finlay was the descover
and Reed the demonstrator, each depend-
ent upon the work of the other, to rid
the world of that dreadful scourge.

Thank you for sharing with me the
progress of the effort to do honor to
these two great men of the Medical
Profession.

With the hope that the long - dreamed of
memorial in Cuba may soon be a reality,
C/2
B5
and that the Museum may preserve
and Enshrine the work of Carlos Finlay
and Walter Reed.
